src.config module

src.data_generation module

src.data_generation.generate_dataset(num_samples, session_output_dir, plot_first_sample_details=False)[source]

src.fem_utils module

src.fem_utils.calculate_l2_error(u_numerical, mesh_type, mesh_dimensions=None, mesh=None)[source]

Calculates the L2 error of the numerical solution against an exact solution. Returns -1.0 if no exact solution is defined for the mesh_type, -2.0 if u_numerical is None.

src.fem_utils.get_solution_based_monitor_function(u_solution, mesh)[source]

Generates a monitor function based on the L2 norm of the gradient of the FEM solution. Returns a NumPy array of nodal values.

src.fem_utils.solve_fem_problem(mesh, mesh_type, mesh_dimensions=None)[source]

Solves a Poisson problem on the given mesh. -Laplace(u) = f u = u_D on boundary

src.fenics_mesh_to_pyg_data module

src.fenics_mesh_to_pyg_data.fenics_mesh_to_pyg_data(mesh, device='cpu', additional_features=None)[source]

Converts a FEniCS (dolfin) mesh to a PyTorch Geometric Data object. Node features (‘x’) include coordinates and optional additional features. ‘pos’ stores only the coordinates for PyG visualization/geometric ops. Edges (‘edge_index’) are defined between nodes sharing a cell.

Parameters:

  • mesh (dolfin.Mesh) – The FEniCS mesh.

  • device (str) – The torch device (‘cuda’ or ‘cpu’).

  • additional_features (np.ndarray, optional) – A NumPy array of shape [num_nodes, num_add_features] to be concatenated with coordinates. Typically, these could be monitor function values.

src.hessian_recovery module

src.hessian_recovery.get_hessian_frobenius_norm_fenics(u_solution, mesh)[source]

Recovers Hessian components and computes the Frobenius norm at nodes. Inspired by Rowbottom et al. (2025) Appendix A.2[cite: 254]. :type u_solution: :param u_solution: The FEM solution (scalar). :type u_solution: dolfin.Function :type mesh: :param mesh: The FEniCS mesh. :type mesh: dolfin.Mesh

Returns:

Nodal values of the Frobenius norm of the Hessian.

Return type:

np.array

src.hessian_recovery.project_tensor_to_scalar_space(tensor_field, V_scalar, name='Projected Scalar')[source]

Projects a component of a tensor field to a scalar FunctionSpace.

Escapes special LaTeX characters in a string.

Formats a time value from seconds to milliseconds.

Formats a number for the stats table, using scientific notation for small values.

src.main module

src.mesh_generators_2 module

src.mesh_generators_2.create_pipe_with_obstacle_mesh_gmsh(pipe_length=3.0, pipe_height=1.0, obstacle_cx_factor=0.3, obstacle_cy_factor=0.5, obstacle_r_factor=0.15, mesh_size_factor=0.1)[source]

Creates a FEniCS mesh of a pipe with a circular obstacle using the Gmsh Python API and loads the .msh file directly into FEniCS.

src.mesh_generators_2.create_square_mesh(nx, ny)[source]

Creates a simple FEniCS UnitSquareMesh. Stores nx and ny in the dimensions dictionary.

src.mesh_utils module

src.mesh_utils.check_mesh_quality(mesh, operation_name='')[source]

Checks mesh quality by looking at minimum cell volume. Returns (bool: quality_ok, float: min_cell_volume_value)

src.mesh_utils.dummy_classical_r_adaptivity(mesh, monitor_values, strength=0.05, mesh_dimensions=None)[source]

Performs a simple r-adaptivity step. Boundary nodes are kept fixed to their original positions. Interior nodes are moved based on the monitor function.

src.mesh_utils.get_boundary_nodes(mesh)[source]

Identifies boundary nodes of a FEniCS mesh.

src.plot_funcs module

Functions for data visualization and logging

src.plot_funcs.cuda_status(device)[source]
Return type:

None

src.plot_funcs.density_plot_matrix(matrix, output='', title='', show=True, **kwargs)[source]

Plot KDE (Kernel Density Estimate), used to get a rough understanding of how the vertexes are spaced. :type matrix: ndarray :param matrix: The input matrix (e.g., node coordinates). :type matrix: np.ndarray :type output: str :param output: Directory to save the plot. :type output: str :type title: str :param title: Custom title for the plot. If empty, a default title is used. :type title: str :type show: bool :param show: Whether to display the plot interactively. :type show: bool

Return type:

None

src.plot_funcs.loss_plot(epoch_count, loss_values, test_loss_values, model_name='', output='', show=True)[source]
Return type:

None

src.plot_funcs.plot_accuracy_vs_cost(classical_costs, classical_accuracies, gat_costs, gat_accuracies, cost_label='Computational Cost (e.g., Nodes)', accuracy_label='FE Solution Error (e.g., L2 Norm)', title='Accuracy vs. Computational Cost Comparison', output='', show=True, **kwargs)[source]
src.plot_funcs.plot_accuracy_vs_time(classical_times, classical_accuracies, gat_times, gat_accuracies, time_label='Inference Time (s)', accuracy_label='FE Solution Error (e.g., L2 Norm)', title='Accuracy vs. Inference Time Comparison', output='', show=True, **kwargs)[source]

Generates a scatter plot comparing the accuracy (error) vs. time of two methods. Lower and to the left is better.

src.plot_funcs.plot_convergence(classical_dofs, classical_errors, gat_dofs, gat_errors, dof_label='Degrees of Freedom (DoF)', error_label='FE Solution Error (e.g., L2 Norm)', title='Convergence Plot', output='', show=True, **kwargs)[source]

Generates a line plot comparing the convergence (error vs. DoF/nodes) of two methods.

class src.utils.Tee(filename, mode='a')[source]
